title: 110_hr2017
content: The Act is titled the "Part-time Student Assistance Act" and refers to amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965. Section 2 of the Act focuses on increasing income protection allowances for working students. The Act, titled the "Part-time Student Assistance Act," amends the Higher Education Act of 1965 by increasing income protection allowances for different categories of students. Dependent students have an allowance of $9,000, independent students without dependents other than a spouse have an allowance of $12,000, and independent students with dependents other than a spouse have an income protection allowance determined by a specific table. The income protection allowance for independent students with dependents other than a spouse is determined by a specific table prescribed by the Secretary under section 478. The income protection allowance for independent students with dependents is determined by a specific table based on family size and number in college. For a family size of 2, the allowance is $17,580 for one college student. The income protection allowance for independent students with dependents is determined by a specific table based on family size and number in college. The table shows increasing amounts for each additional college student, with the highest allowance being $19,390 for a family size of 6 with one college student. The Secretary will publish revised tables of income protection allowances for each academic year after 1993-1994, based on the estimated percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index. The Secretary will publish revised tables of income protection allowances for independent students with dependents other than a spouse for each academic year after 2007-2008. The tables will be adjusted based on the estimated percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index, rounded to the nearest $10. SEC. 3 amends Section 480(a)(2) to exempt earned income credits from income calculation. SEC. 4 defines child care as parents in school. Amendments include increasing the minimum grant amount to $30,000, lowering the threshold for eligible institutions to $250,000, changing income eligibility criteria, adding a requirement for publicity of grant availability, and authorizing appropriations of $75,000,000 for fiscal year 2008. YEAR-ROUND PELL GRANTS. Section 401 (20 U.S.C. 1070a) is amended to establish a year-round Pell grant pilot program allowing up to 200 institutions of higher education to participate. The program enables students to receive two Federal Pell Grants in an academic year. The year-round Pell grant pilot program allows students to receive two Federal Pell Grants in one calendar year, accelerating progress towards their degree objectives by enrolling for 12 months at participating institutions. Institutions must commit to improving completion rates to participate in the program. The year-round Pell grant pilot program requires institutions to improve completion and graduation rates by specific percentages within a set period. The Secretary will evaluate the program and report to Congress by October 1, 2011, with the authority ending on October 1, 2013. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL FIPSE PROGRAM. The purpose of this section is to allow a demonstration program monitored by the Department of Education to test measures for improving higher education availability for part-time students, increase access for part-time students, and determine effective assistance. A new program is authorized to create a holistic approach for addressing the needs of part-time students. The section aims to establish a program addressing the needs of part-time students at select institutions through grants, leveraging funds, child care, and tailored remedial courses. Eligible entities must apply for grants following specified procedures set by the Secretary. The regulation establishes a formal procedure for grant applications under subsection (b)(9) and requires annual evaluations of the program's effectiveness, including goals achievement, student participation, and potential law changes to support part-time students in higher education. The regulation sets a process for grant applications under subsection (b)(9) and mandates yearly evaluations of the program's success, focusing on goals achievement, student participation, and funding support for part-time students in higher education. Authorization of appropriations includes $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and necessary sums for the following five years.
